bibl.title: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, April 8, 1900

div1.p: Louise Kean writes to her mother about consultations to secure Jefferson Randolph Kean's position as Chief Surgeon of General Lee's Province.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, April 8, 1900
div1.p:
I have been so
busy all week that
I put off writing from
day to day, until here
is Sunday again, and
just a week since I
last wrote you. In
the meantime, I have
finished my pink dress
and made three very
pretty shirt waists from
the white stuff Art
sent me last fall. I
enclose a check for $20.,
which will, I think
pay Art for the nain-
sook you say he has
sent, and likewise for
Martha's aprons and the
little night gowns you
were to have made.

I am glad to hear you
can have my dress
made so quickly, and
I am waiting anxiously
for your next letter to
hear more about it.
Please, mother, keep an
account of what it
costs and my cape, for
the first of next month I will be able
to send more money, and I don't want
you to spend very much of yours
on me; I don't suppose you will be
satisfied unless you spend some.

You will rejoice with me that it
seems as if Rannie's position is def-
initely fixed, and that the decision has
been that he is to remain as the
Chief Surgeon of Gen. Lee's enlarged prov-
ince. That is what we wanted and
the General was so sweet about it,
this is the way it came about. There
were renewed attempts to get Rannie
sent to Havana, and Gen. Wood told
Gen. L. he thought Dr. Gorgas would be
his Chief Surgeon, and that he would
have Dr. Ives and Dr. Kean look after
Havana. So our General told Rannie
to consult with Dr. Gorgas, and they
could decide which would be the Sani-
tary Officer and he would try to fix
it the way they wanted
it. As we knew, Rannie
found Dr. Gorgas anxious
to have Havana and
delighted to have Rannie
left as Gen. Lee's Chief
Surgeon, so together they
went to the Palace
where Gen. Lee and Gen.
Wood were in consul-
tation, and told Gen. L.
their wishes, and it
was arranged accordingly.
Tho' Gen. W. showed some
reluctance, so I am sure
Gen. Ludlow and Col. Black
had been talking to him
about Dr. Gorgas.
Another joyful thing is
that Gen. Lee is to
keep his headquarters
out here for the summer,
for they do not wish
to have any more non-
immunes in the city than
they can help. So you
see every thing is turn-
ing out nicely, for six
months anyhow, and
Gen. Ludlow leaves
next Saturday, so I
think affairs are set-
tled. Mrs. Wood is
thinking seriously of
spending the summer in Cuba,
and if she does she will come to
Quemados.

Wednesday Rannie and I drove over to
see Mrs. Ladd and Mrs. Steadman,
who had stopped there on her way
north. We drove over the Gen.'s new
road, which is partially finished
and the pontoon bridge is across the
river for use until a fine iron one
can be put in place. It is going
to be a beautiful calzada, running
along the top of the ridge within
right of the sea all the way.
This afternoon there is to be a foot-
ball game between a team of the
officers and a team of Cubans. I
cannot imagine anything more fool-
ish, for, of course, none of the men
are in training and it is a
very warm day. Poor Mrs. Lee is
still in her room, so I am going
with the General in
the big carriage. Rannie
Martha and Caz are
going in the “Ancestreal
coach”.

Every time Mrs. Lee ven-
tures out of her room
she gets a relapse of
both bronchitis and
asthma. You have no
idea how thin she
has gotten. I have
started a “feeding up”
process of milk punches
at night etc., and Rannie
has found something
that seems to relieve
her spasms, so I trust
she will soon have
a decided turn for
the better.

Please thank father
for his letter and for
ordering the oil, which
I think will be here on
the Sedgewick either
today or tomorrow.

The foot ball game was
a great success. The poor
Cubanos were not in
it, tho' we hear they
had been practicing, and
were willing to bet even money
on their team! All our men played
very well- Mr. Humphrey is the hero,
having made a fine run. Mr. Reeder
played center. It was really great fun.

Caz is going to take this letter
in to post it for me so goodnight.
With love to all
